title: Overflowing Trafalgar Square fountain threatens to flood out protesters
text:
To view this video please enable JavaScript, and consider upgrading to a web browser that supports HTML5 video

Protesters camping in Trafalgar Square overnight were at threat of being flooded out after the iconic fountain began overflowing.

Extinction Rebellion this morning tweeted a video of water spilling onto the ground where activists had put down sand bags.

The group said campers made a human chain and directed the water away from a kitchen area at their makeshift camp site using around 40 of the sand bags.

It was still overflowing this morning, a spokesperson for the group said.

They told Metro.co.uk that protesters were undeterred by the flood risk and were staying in place at the site.

Water flooding the area surrounding Trafalgar Square’s fountain (Picture: @XRebellionUK)

XR protesters’ tents in Trafalgar Square overnight (Picture: PA)

Police have arrested around 800 people during demonstrations on Whitehall this week (Picture: Getty)

In 2011, two Trafalgar Square fountains overflowed leading to an eight-hour closure of Charing Cross Tube station underneath.

Water seeped into the pump room for the fountains and traffic lights failed around the square when power was lost.

Metro.co.uk have contacted City Hall, who are responsible for Trafalgar Square and its fountains, for comment.

XR activists today begin what they are calling a three-day ‘Hong Kong-style’ takeover of London City Airport.

So far a handful of protesters have been turned away with a heavy security presence in place only allowing people in if they show they have a valid boarding pass for a flight today.

The protest group says its members intend to ‘peacefully occupy and shut down’ the terminal building by lying, sitting or gluing themselves in front of the departure and arrival gates at the east London airport.

London City Airport is the target for today’s action (Picture: Metro.co.uk)

Police were seen barricaded doors to the airport and are only allowing people who show boarding passes to get into the airport terminal (Picture: Metro.co.uk)

If they do not make it into the building, they plan to occupy the airport’s access road and DLR station, XR said.

Advertisement

Advertisement

The latest protest is against the climate impact of flying and the Government’s ongoing support of airport expansion.

Extinction Rebellion said hundreds of people have already signed up to take part in the protest, which will seem them ‘non-violently use their bodies’ to close the airport.

Hundreds of police officers are being drafted in from across England and Wales to help the Metropolitan Police with the protests, which are now in their third day.

On Tuesday, police began cutting down tents across London to get protesters to move on (Picture: Rex)

Officers started dismantling tents while activists were still sat inside (Picture: Getty)

Activists have been camped on roads around Parliament Square and Whitehall since Monday calling for urgent action on climate change and wildlife.

The Metropolitan Police confirmed that 800 people had been arrested since Monday, with another 220 detained on Wednesday.

Metropolitan Police deputy assistant commissioner Laurence Taylor said there are plans in place to intervene and ‘deal proactively’ with anyone who has the intention of shutting down the airport.

A London City Airport spokesman said they were working with the Met Police to prepare for protests.
